#### Load libraries 

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
list.of.packages <- c("ggplot2", "tidyverse", "car", "arm", "here") #add new libraries here 
new.packages <- list.of.packages[!(list.of.packages %in% installed.packages()[,"Package"])]
if(length(new.packages)) install.packages(new.packages)

# Load all libraries 
lapply(list.of.packages, FUN = function(X) {
  do.call("require", list(X)) 
})
```

#### Load data and reformat 

```{r}
larvae.size <- read.csv(here("raw-data", "2019-08_new-larvae-measurements.csv"), header=T, stringsAsFactors = F)
larvae.size[c("Sample", "Population", "Temperature", "pH")] <- lapply(larvae.size[c("Sample", "Population", "Temperature", "pH")], factor)
larvae.size$DateCollected <- as.Date(larvae.size$DateCollected, format = "%m/%d/%y")
```

#### Correct size data 

Scope was not calibrated accurately. Based on measurements of 12 known lengths, multiply lengths by 1.405669

MaxFeret = best estimate of shell width (length running parallel to hinge) 
MinFeret = best estimate of shell heigh (length running perpendicular to hinge) 

```{r}
larvae.size$MaxFeret.cor <- larvae.size$MaxFeret*1.405669 
larvae.size$MinFeret.cor <- larvae.size$MinFeret*1.405669 
```

Inspect size data  

```{r}
summary(larvae.size[c("Length", "Width", "MaxFeret", "MinFeret", "MaxFeret90", "MaxFeret.cor", "MinFeret.cor")]) 
aggregate(MaxFeret.cor ~ Temperature+pH, larvae.size, mean) 
aggregate(MinFeret.cor ~ Temperature+pH, larvae.size, mean)
hist(larvae.size$MaxFeret.cor, breaks = 100)
hist(larvae.size$MinFeret.cor, breaks = 100)
```

#### How many samples do I have size data for, per group? 

The number of larval samples, which were collect from volitional spawn w/n treatments, is unequal among treatments. Unbalanced design (need to account for this in stats) 

Cohort + Temperature + pH 
```{r}
larvae.size %>% filter(Sample!=506) %>% #for size stats remove sample 506 since not enough measurements 
          group_by(Population, Temperature, pH) %>%
          summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))
```

Just Temperature + pH (all cohorts combined - how i will assess)

```{r}
larvae.size %>%
          group_by(Temperature, pH) %>% filter(Population!="Oyster Bay C2" ) %>%
          summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))
```


### Generate initial plots  

Inspect all larval length data (not yet summarized for each larval group)

- Shell width ~ shell height, color coded by parental treatment 
- Shell width by parental treatment within each cohort 
- Shell height by parental treatment within each cohort 

```{r, echo=FALSE}
print(max.min.all <- ggplot(subset(larvae.size, MinFeret.cor>80), aes(x=MinFeret, y=MaxFeret)) + geom_point(size=.5, aes(color=Temperature:pH)) + theme_bw(base_size = 12) + labs(title="Larval shell size upon release", y=("Max Feret Diameter (~width), (um)"), x="Min Feret Diameter (~height),") + theme(text = element_text(size = 14)) + scale_color_manual(values=c("blue", "forestgreen", "orange", "red")))

print(max.all <- ggplot(larvae.size, aes(x=Population, y=MaxFeret)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color=Temperature:pH)) + theme_bw(base_size = 12) + labs(title="Larval shell width (Max Feret) by cohort & treatment", y=("Max. Feret Diameter (um)"), x="Cohort") + theme(text = element_text(size = 14)) + scale_color_manual(values=c("blue", "forestgreen", "orange", "red")))

print(min.all <- ggplot(larvae.size, aes(x=Population, y=MinFeret)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color=Temperature:pH)) + theme_bw(base_size = 12) + labs(title="Larval shell height (Min Feret) by cohort & treatment", y=("Min. Feret Diameter (um)"), x="Cohort") + theme(text = element_text(size = 14)) + scale_color_manual(values=c("blue", "forestgreen", "orange", "red")))

#Check circularity to ensure measurements were not biased by some angled groups of larvae 
print(circ.all <- ggplot(larvae.size, aes(x=Population, y=Circularity)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color=Temperature:pH)) + theme_bw(base_size = 12) + labs(title="Circularity by cohort & treatment", y=("Min. Feret Diameter (um)"), x="Cohort") + theme(text = element_text(size = 14)) + scale_color_manual(values=c("blue", "forestgreen", "orange", "red")))

#Check circularity to ensure measurements were not biased by some angled groups of larvae 
print(cohort.all <- ggplot(larvae.size, aes(x=Population, y=MaxFeret)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color=Population)) + theme_bw(base_size = 12) + labs(title="Shell width upon release, by cohort", y=("Max. Feret Diameter (um)"), x="Cohort") + theme(text = element_text(size = 14)) + scale_color_manual(values=c("blue", "forestgreen", "orange", "red")))
```

####  Summarize mean shell height and width for each larval sample   

```{r}
larvae.size.mean <- larvae.size %>% 
          group_by(Population, Temperature, pH, Sample) %>%
          summarise(MaxFeret.mean=mean(MaxFeret.cor), MinFeret.mean=mean(MinFeret.cor),
                    Circ.mean=mean(Circularity),  date=median(DateCollected), n=n())

save(larvae.size.mean, file = "../results/larvae.size.mean")
```

## Statistical analyses

Test for length differences among parental temp, pH treats 

NOTE: unbalanced design, so need to use either Type II or Type III SS. See nice explanation here:  [https://www.r-bloggers.com/anova-%E2%80%93-type-iiiiii-ss-explained/](https://www.r-bloggers.com/anova-%E2%80%93-type-iiiiii-ss-explained/)

####  Test Max. Feret Diameter (best estimate for larval width)

Check ANOVA assumptions 

```{r}
hist(larvae.size.mean$MaxFeret.mean)
shapiro.test(larvae.size.mean$MaxFeret.mean)
bartlett.test(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH, data=larvae.size.mean)
bartlett.test(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature, data=larvae.size.mean)
```

Test for sign. differences among parental treatments using 

```{r}
require(nlme)
summary(lme(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, random=~1|Population, data=larvae.size.mean), type="II")
Anova(lme(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, random=~1|Population, data=larvae.size.mean), type="II") #Assess using type III sums of squares, where I look at effects of pH and temperature and pH:temp interaction after controlling for the other factors, and since unbalanced design should not use type I 

# Sign. w/o OB2? 
Anova(lme(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, random=~1|Population, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type="II") #yes
```

Test for sign. differences among parental treatments within populations that have sufficient measurements 

```{r}
larvae.size %>%
          group_by(Temperature, pH) %>% filter(Population!="Oyster Bay C2" ) %>%
          summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))

larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Dabob Bay") %>% group_by(Temperature, pH) %>% summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))
Anova(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Dabob Bay"))), type="II")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Dabob Bay"))))

larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Fidalgo Bay") %>% group_by(Temperature, pH) %>% summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))
Anova(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Fidalgo Bay"))), type="II")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Fidalgo Bay"))))

larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Oyster Bay C1") %>% group_by(Temperature, pH) %>% summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))
Anova(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Oyster Bay C1"))), type="II")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Oyster Bay C1"))))

larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Oyster Bay C2") %>% group_by(Temperature, pH) %>% summarise(count= n_distinct(Sample))
Anova(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Oyster Bay C2"))), type="II")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=(larvae.size.mean %>% filter(Population=="Oyster Bay C2"))))

# All in one model 
Anova(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Population*Temperature*pH, data=larvae.size.mean), type=2) 

# Pairwise comparisons to see which are significant within populations- Oyster Bay C1 10low vs 6ambient
TukeyHSD(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Population+Temperature+pH+Population:Temperature:pH, data=larvae.size.mean), type=2)$`Population:Temperature:pH` %>% as.data.frame() %>% filter(`p adj`<0.05)
```
Test for sign. differences among parental treatments within population - separate test for each population 

```{r}
print("Dabob Bay")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Dabob Bay")))  #interaction, but no main effect 
TukeyHSD(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature:pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Dabob Bay")))  # no sign. pairwise  

print("Fidalgo Bay")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Fidalgo Bay")))  #interaction, but no main effect 
TukeyHSD(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature + Temperature:pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Fidalgo Bay")))  # 10low larger than 6 low 

print("Oyster Bay C1")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Oyster Bay C1" & Sample!="506")))  #temp & pH significant difference 
TukeyHSD(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Oyster Bay C1")))  # and 10amb-6 amb, 6low-6amb, 10low-6amb = largest difference 

print("Oyster Bay C2")
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Oyster Bay C2")))  #no effects 
```


Try mixed effect model, with Population as random effect

```{r}
display(lmer(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH + (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean))
Anova(lmer(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH + (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean), type=2)

display(lmer(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH+ (1|Population), data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2"))) 
Anova(lmer(MaxFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH + (1|Population), data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #with Pop as random effect and using type II SS, still sign. influence of temp and pH 
```
#### Test min Feret Diameter (best estimate for larval height)

```{r}
hist(larvae.size.mean$MinFeret.mean)
shapiro.test(larvae.size.mean$MinFeret.mean)
bartlett.test(MinFeret.mean ~ pH, data=larvae.size.mean)
bartlett.test(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature, data=larvae.size.mean)
anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature + pH + Temperature:pH, data=larvae.size.mean)) #no interaction. Assess using type II sums of squares, where I look at effects of pH and temperature after controlling for the other factor 
Anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=larvae.size.mean), type=2) #both sign. 
summary(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH, data=larvae.size.mean)) # Fit not great, though 
TukeyHSD(aov(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH, data=larvae.size.mean), type=2) #both sign. 
```

Try mixed effect model, with Population as random effect

```{r}
display(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH + (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean))
Anova(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature*pH + (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean), type=2)
display(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH+ (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean)) 
Anova(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature+pH + (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean), type=2) #with Pop as random effect and using type II SS, still sign. influence of temp and pH 

Anova(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ pH + (1|Population), data=larvae.size.mean), type=2) #with Pop as random effect and using type II SS, still sign. influence of pH 


# Don't include Oyster Bay C2 
Anova(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ Temperature + (1|Population), data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #with Pop as random effect and using type II SS, still sign. influence of pH 
Anova(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ pH + (1|Population), data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #with Pop as random effect and using type II SS, still sign. influence of pH 
```

#### Test sign. diff among cohorts only 

```{r}
summary(aov(MinFeret.mean ~ Population, data=larvae.size.mean)) #no 
summary(aov(MaxFeret.mean ~ Population, data=larvae.size.mean)) #no 
```

### Check out larval sizes for samples I already sequenced last year

```{r}
quant2018 <-  as.factor(c(41, 26, 32, 10, 48, 77)) #sample numbers for larvae already sequenced (only n=3 per treat)
quant2018 <- larvae.size[larvae.size$Sample %in% quant2018,]
hist(quant2018$MaxFeret)
shapiro.test(log(quant2018$MaxFeret))
ggplot(quant2018, aes(x=Temperature:pH, y=MaxFeret)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_jitter() + theme_bw(base_size = 14) + labs(title="Larval shell  by treatment", y=("size (um)"), x="Treatment") + theme(text = element_text(size = 16)) 
kruskal.test(quant2018$MaxFeret, g = quant2018$pH) #sign. different - 10-low larger.  
```

# IMPORTANT - LARVAL DATA ANALYSIS AS OF 6/5/2021

# SHELL WIDTH 
# HERE WE DON'T INCLUDE OYSTER BAY C2  
```{r}
# First test for interaction between pH and temp 
Anova(lmer(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH*Temperature + (1|Population), 
           data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #with Pop as random effect 

Anova(lm(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH*Temperature, 
         data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #across all populations 
# PH AND TEMPERATURE DO NOT INTERACT, move on to only analyze pH effects, BUT report temp stats in supp 

# Only looking at pH 
Anova(lm(MaxFeret.mean ~ Population+pH, 
           data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) 

# mixed effect model with popullation as random
Anova(lmer(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH + (1|Population), 
           data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) 

# Now look at effect of pH within each cohort 
Anova(lm(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Dabob Bay")), type=2) #No effect  
Anova(lm(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Fidalgo Bay")), type=2) #No effect  
Anova(lm(MaxFeret.mean ~ pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Oyster Bay C1")), type=2) #Yes effect  

```

# SHELL HEIGHT 
# HERE WE DON'T INCLUDE OYSTER BAY C2  
```{r}
# First test for interaction between pH and temp 
Anova(lmer(MinFeret.mean ~ pH*Temperature + (1|Population), 
           data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #with Pop as random effect 

Anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ pH*Temperature, 
         data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) #across all populations 
# PH AND TEMPERATURE DO NOT INTERACT, move on to only analyze pH effects, BUT report temp stats in supp 

# Only looking at pH 
Anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ Population+pH, 
           data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population!="Oyster Bay C2")), type=2) 

# Now look at effect of pH within each cohort 
Anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Dabob Bay")), type=2) #No effect  
Anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Fidalgo Bay")), type=2) #No effect  
Anova(lm(MinFeret.mean ~ pH, data=subset(larvae.size.mean, Population=="Oyster Bay C1")), type=2) #Yes effect  
```
